ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Day-lighting for common internal corridors)


    1. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Law and National Development if the Housing and Development Board authorities will consider providing some lighting during day-light hours for common internal corridors in Housing and Development Board housing blocks.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, all lights along the common corridors and stair-cases of Housing and Development Board flats are controlled by time switches. They are switched on automatically at sunset and are switched off automatically at sunrise. In order to provide some lights during the day for internal corridors, re-wiring on a substantial scale is required. This would be costly. However, the Board will consider providing some lights in some internal corridors which have very poor natural light.

    Sir, during the debate on the Development Estimates last year, the Minister for Law and National Development said that he hoped the Member for Katong would support his project for the building of the new subordinate court complex. In view of the remarks I made regarding the slow progress d building that was going on, I would certainly support this project wholeheartedly, because a place where justice is administered should reflect the fresh, crisp, and clean atmosphere and appearance which characterises Singapore. I hope that it will not be necessary before long for those who are required to appear in court for one reason or another to experience the gloomy atmosphere of dilapidation that characterises the present subordinate courts.

    It is, therefore, with some dismay that I note that of the $2 million voted for last year, a large sum has been re-voted this year, the actual amount spent being less than $200,000.     The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am in the fortunate position of being able to report some progress in respect of our Mass Transit Planning Unit. An application has been made to the United Nations Development Programme for assistance to undertake a study of this Mass Transit System. The objective of the study is, firstly, to compare the economic feasibility of alternative mass transit systems in the metropolitan areas, in relation to alternative pricing policies for urban transport. Secondly, to recommend a long-range transport investment programme, which includes mass transport facilities. And, thirdly, to define specific investment projects as well as the implementation programme.

    This study will be guided by a steering committee of seven officials under the Ministry of Communications and will be carried out by consultants employed by the World Bank, which is the participating and executing agency. The study will take about 15 months. Five international consulting firms two from the United States,

one each from France, Germany, and the United Kingdom have been asked by the World Bank to submit proposals, and the study is expected to commence sometime in the middle of this year.

    Local counterpart and accounting staff are being provided by Government and, in this connection, I am pleased to say that four local officers have been sent overseas for training under the U.N.D.P./World Bank fellowships. They are now under training in the United States, Japan, and Europe.

    We have also found suitable accommodation to house the Mass Transit Planning Unit in a P.S.A. bungalow known as the "Golden Bell", and we have provided $855,000 for the coming year to meet Government contribution towards the project. This amount is to provide for the salaries of the local counterpart and other subordinate staff, rental of accommodation, P.U.B, services, etc.

    Sir, can the Minister inform the House as to what is this Airport Information Dissemination System? I understand that it is not a closed circuit T.V.; but that it works on an electronic principle, which is an improvement over the old fashioned closed circuit television.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Punggol is right in stating that the Airport Information Dissemination System, in short, AIDS, is an electronic data display system for our air traffic controllers and is an improvement over what was previously known as the closed circuit television system. AIDS will display air traffic flight data and other associated information to the air traffic controllers, and thus enabling them to exercise their air traffic control functions efficiently. The current practice is done through an intercommunication system, which is hardly an efficient system. It is slow because of the need to transmit data to multiple addresses and also because of the writing work load involved at each receiving unit. The existing system with its heavy manual work load will not be

Column: 1157

able to cope with the increasing air traffic passing through Paya Lebar Airport. Accordingly, it is necessary to provide an electronic information dissemination system which will not only speed up the work of air traffic controllers but will also relieve them of their manual work, thereby enabling them to concentrate on other essential functions.

    The project is estimated to cost $250,000 in all, but $50,000 have been provided for the fiscal year, 1972-73, for initial preparatory work. The scheme is planned for commissioning in two years' time, 1974. I would like to add further that AIDS will form an integral part of the future air traffic control system at the Paya Lebar Airport when other facilities, such as long-range surveillance radar, are implemented around 1975. In the coming years of supersonic air travel, it is imperative that the air traffic controllers be provided with suitable and adequate tools to enable them to perform their functions efficiently to match the speed of supersonic aircraft. The electronic AIDS is such a tool.

    And now there is a request for a revote. With the development of Nanyang University, there will be more students requiring hostel facilities in Nanyang University.     Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, as there are a few amendments on the Order Paper Supplement regarding the development of Nanyang University, I would like to take this opportunity, in answering the first question from the Member for Delta, to make clear the philosophy of the physical development of a university. Universities are not built and developed just for today, for tomorrow, or for the year. They are built to stay for hundreds of years. Therefore, any physical development programme must be considered in the greatest detail. We cannot build a cluster of concrete buildings just because there happened to be some empty space, or because it is the most suitable development to meet the needs for the present. I believe it is in this context that the Member for Jurong last year asked whether a Master Plan was being prepared for the Nanyang University. The building of students hostels and other forms of development are part and parcel of the total physical development of the Nanyang University, and therefore the matter has to be looked, into very closely.
